an3.40:4.1: “There are, mendicants, these three things to put in charge.
an3.40:4.3: Putting oneself, the world, or the teaching in charge.
an3.40:4.4: And what, mendicants, is putting oneself in charge?
an3.40:4.5: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:
an3.40:4.6: ‘I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe,
an3.40:4.7: alms-food, lodgings, or rebirth in this or that state.
an3.40:4.8: But I was overwhelmed by birth, old age, and death; by sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress. I was overwhelmed by suffering, mired in suffering.
an3.40:4.9: And I thought, ‘Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’
an3.40:4.10: But it would not be appropriate for me to seek sensual pleasures like those I left behind when I went forth, or even worse.’
an3.40:4.12: ‘My energy shall be roused up and vigorous, mindfulness shall be established and lucid, my body shall be tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind shall be unified in samādhi.’
an3.40:4.13: Putting themselves in charge, they give up the unwholesome and develop the wholesome, they give up the blameworthy and develop the blameless, and they keep themselves pure.
an3.40:4.14: This is called putting oneself in charge.
an3.40:5.1: And what, mendicants, is putting the world in charge?
an3.40:5.2: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:
an3.40:5.3: ‘I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe,
an3.40:5.4: alms-food, lodgings, or rebirth in this or that state.
an3.40:5.5: But I was overwhelmed by birth, old age, and death, by sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress. I was overwhelmed by suffering, mired in suffering.
an3.40:5.6: And I thought, ‘Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’
an3.40:5.7: And now, since I’ve now gone forth, I might have sensual, malicious, or cruel thoughts. But the population of the world is large,
an3.40:5.8: and there are ascetics and brahmins who have psychic powers—they’re clairvoyant, and can read the minds of others.
an3.40:5.9: They see far without being seen, even by those close; and they understand the minds of others.
an3.40:5.11: ‘Look at this person from a good family; they’ve gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, but they’re living mixed up with bad, unwholesome qualities.’
an3.40:5.12: And there are gods, too, who have psychic powers—they’re clairvoyant, and can read the minds of others.
an3.40:5.13: They see far without being seen, even by those close; and they understand the minds of others.
an3.40:5.15: ‘Look at this person from a good family; they’ve gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, but they’re living mixed up with bad, unwholesome qualities.’
an3.40:5.17: ‘My energy shall be roused up and vigorous, mindfulness shall be established and lucid, my body shall be tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind shall be unified in samādhi.’
an3.40:5.18: Putting the world in charge, they give up the unwholesome and develop the wholesome, they give up the blameworthy and develop the blameless, and they keep themselves pure.
an3.40:5.19: This is called putting the world in charge.
an3.40:6.1: And what, mendicants, is putting the teaching in charge?
an3.40:6.2: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:
an3.40:6.3: ‘I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe,
an3.40:6.4: alms-food, lodgings, or rebirth in this or that state.
an3.40:6.5: But I was overwhelmed by birth, old age, and death, by sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress. I was overwhelmed by suffering, mired in suffering.
an3.40:6.6: And I thought, ‘Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’
an3.40:6.7: The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—realizable in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.
an3.40:6.8: I have spiritual companions who live knowing and seeing.
an3.40:6.9: Now that I’ve gone forth in this well explained teaching and training, it would not be appropriate for me to live lazy and heedless.
an3.40:6.11: ‘My energy shall be roused up and vigorous, mindfulness shall be established and lucid, my body shall be tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind shall be unified in samādhi.’
an3.40:6.12: Putting the teaching in charge, they give up the unwholesome and develop the wholesome, they give up the blameworthy and develop the blameless, and they keep themselves pure.
an3.40:6.13: This is called putting the teaching in charge.
an3.40:6.14: These are the three things to put in charge.”
an3.40:7.2: for someone who does bad deeds.
an3.40:7.4: whether you’ve lied or told the truth.
an3.40:8.1: When you witness your good self,
an3.40:9.1: The gods and the Realized One see
an3.40:9.2: the fool who lives unjustly in the world.
an3.40:9.3: So with yourself in charge, live mindfully;
an3.40:9.4: with the world in charge, be self-disciplined and practice absorption;
an3.40:9.5: with the teaching in charge, live in line with that teaching:
an3.40:9.6: a sage who tries for the truth doesn’t deteriorate.
an3.40:10.2: one who tries reaches the end of birth.
an3.40:10.4: that sage identifies with nothing at all.”
